bibl.title: [Letter] 1817 Nov. 18 [to] James Winchester / Jno. Navarre
bibl.author: Navarre, Jno.
bibl.note: This is a letter from Jno. Navarre to James Winchester dated November 18, 1817, explaining the death of Mrs. Navarre and the return of some of Winchester's personal belongings.

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 2.1 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

div1.p:
having a long time wished to hear from you but not being gratified, I now have to inform you, that mrs. Navarre pased on the 22n day of Janey. 1870 your watch, specticls, & penknife that is to say I think thay belonged to you, She picked them up on the hastened morning of the destruction of your property and mine, and put them in her breasts; the watch I put into the hands of Col. Butler, of Kentucky to deliver it to you, which I hope you have recieved, I now forward the specticles & penknife, with Col. Bathers recept for the watch by my friend Col. John Anderson whom takes on my claim on government for my losses, and hope you will assist him by your certificat that you had a Military deposit in my house
house; & will not undertake to give you a detail of my sufferance after that fatal morning untill the return of the American troops to this Country but my frind if he has the Honor of Seeing you will give it in fall.
div1.closer:
hopping you enjoy good health I have the honor to be your most obedt & Humble Servnt Jno Navarre
Genrl. James Winchester Tennessee H. by Col. John Anderson
